review.title: A Survey of Classification Techniques in the Area of Big Data
review.abstract: Big Data concern large-volume, growing data sets that are complex and have multiple autonomous sources. Earlier technologies were not able to handle storage and processing of huge data thus Big Data concept comes into existence. This is a tedious job for users unstructured data. So, there should be some mechanism which classify unstructured data into organized form which helps user to easily access required data. Classification techniques over big transactional database provide required data to the users from large datasets more simple way. There are two main classification techniques, supervised and unsupervised. In this paper we focused on to study of different supervised classification techniques. Further this paper shows a advantages and limitations.
histories: 7 pages, 3 figures, 2 tables in IJAFRC, Vol.1, Issue 11, November 2014, ISSN: 2348-4853
review.COMMENTS: 7 pages, 3 figures, 2 tables in IJAFRC, Vol.1, Issue 11, November 2014, ISSN: 2348-4853

metadata.title: A Survey of Classification Techniques in the Area of Big Data

sections.text: This year, it has come to the point where it only takes one year to get there, to get to the point where it is able to unfold.

sections.heading: 2. OVERVIEW OF CLASSIFICATION
sections.text: Classification is one of the data mining techniques that classifies unstructured data into structured classes and groups and helps the user discover knowledge and plan for the future [3]. Classification ensures intelligent decision-making. There are two phases of classification, first the learning phase, in which huge training data sets are provided and analyzed, then rules and patterns. Then the execution of the second phase, which is the evaluation or verification of data sets and archives of the accuracy of a classification pattern, begins. In this section, supervised classification methods such as Decision Tree and Support Vector Machine are briefly described.

sections.heading: 2.1 SUPERVISED METHODS
sections.text: Problems involving classification are considered to be instances of a branch of machine learning called "supervised learning." [5] In this case, the machine is given a "training set" of correctly classified data instances in the first stage, and then the algorithm developed from this "learning" is used for the next stage of prediction; the opposite is "unsupervised learning," in which the data is classified into categories based on some similarity of input parameters in the data. Monitored data mining techniques are appropriate when we have a certain target value so that we can predict about our data [8]. The targets can have two or more possible outcomes or even be a continuous numerical value. To use these methods, we ideally have a subset of training data (observations and measurements) for which this target value is already known. Training data includes both the input and the desired results.

sections.heading: 1. Decision Tree (DT)
sections.text: The decision is ideal to process the large amount of data. DT is a basic means to increase the efficiency and accuracy of this data.

sections.heading: 2. Support Vector Machine (SVM)
sections.text: This year it is so far that it will only be a matter of time before it is ready, until it is ready.

sections.heading: IV. CONCLUSION
sections.text: In this report, we saw the different classification techniques in the field of big data. Both classification techniques are better suited than the other classification techniques. We also have a table showing the advantages and disadvantages of the different classification techniques. [1] Each classification technology has a different accuracy and predictors. [2] The classification efficiency of the SVM algorithm was better than the DT algorithm.

referenceMentions.context: Big data framework is divided into three tiers as shown in figure 1, to handle the above challenges [1].
Data privacy and domain knowledge is the Tier II which focuses on semantics and domain knowledge for different Big Data applications [9].

There are three stages in Tier III, as shown in Figure 2, (a) Sparse, heterogeneous, uncertain, incomplete and multisource data are pre-processed by data fusion techniques; (b) Complex and dynamic data are mined after pre-processing; (c) The global knowledge obtained by local learning and model fusion is tested and relevant information is feedback to the preprocessing stage [1].
Big Data is now part of every sector and function of the global economy [7].
A typical domain like stock market data are constantly generating a large quantity of information such as bids, buys and puts, in every single seconds [2].

Classification technique is used to solve the above challenges which classify the big data according to the format of the data that must be processed, the type of analysis to be applied, the processing techniques at work, and the data sources for the data that the target system is required to acquire, load, process, analyze and store [4].
Classification is one of the data mining technique that classifies unstructured data into the structured class and groups and it helps to user for knowledge discovery and future plan [3].
Problems which involve classification are considered to be instances of a branch of machine learning called as “supervised learning” [5].
Supervised Data Mining techniques are appropriate when we have a specific target value, so we can predict about our data [8].
Decision Tree algorithm is good at tuning between precision which can be trained very fast and provide sound results on those classification data [2].
5 algorithm performs well in short time and it is robust in nature as well as simple to understand [10].
SVM can make use of certain kernels to reveal efficiently in quantum form the largest eigenvalues and corresponding eigenvectors of the training data overlap (kernel) and covariance matrices [2].
To overcome this problem, Clustering-Based SVM (CB-SVM) comes into picture for scalability and reliability of SVM classification [6].

metadata.abstractText: Big Data concern large-volume, growing data sets that are complex and have multiple autonomous sources. Earlier technologies were not able to handle storage and processing of huge data thus Big Data concept comes into existence. This is a tedious job for users to identify accurate data from huge unstructured data. So, there should be some mechanism which classify unstructured data into organized form which helps user to easily access required data. Classification techniques over big transactional database provide required data to the users from large datasets more simple way. There are two main classification techniques, supervised and unsupervised. In this paper we focused on to study of different supervised classification techniques. Further this paper shows application of each technique and their advantages and limitations.
